attributes.title: Exploring Social and Group Dynamics of Tax Compliance: A Conjoint Experiment Among Zambian Taxpayers

q1.value: Exploring Social and Group Dynamics of Tax Compliance: A Conjoint Experiment Among Zambian Taxpayers

q2.value: Brigitte Seim | Daniel Pemstein | Twivwe Siwale

q5.value: We acknowledge the support of the International Growth Centre in funding this project.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: An efficient and well-functioning tax system is a necessary foundation for any country to achieve economic development. One of the key features of a good tax system is the level of tax compliance amongst economic players. In Zambia, tax compliance rates are very low, especially among the Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs). Filing compliance among these taxpayers has been declining since 2010. In 2016, taxes paid by MSMEs only contributed about 15% of the Zambia Revenue Authority’s (ZRA) collections. As part of a multi-phase research project, we conduct a survey that unpacks the barriers to tax compliance among this group of taxpayers. Along with exploring many of the oft-cited barriers to tax compliance, such as low rates of monitoring and enforcement of the tax law, a conjoint experiment sheds light on the social and group-level dynamics of tax compliance and a list experiment refines our measures of tax compliance. Here, we present the pre-analysis plan for the conjoint and list experiments.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1: MSME operators who rely more on public services will be more likely to pay taxes than those that who rely less on public services. Hypothesis 2: MSME operators are more willing to pay their taxes when norms supporting tax-paying are high. Hypothesis 3: MSME operators are more willing to pay their taxes when business associations act as tax collectors. Hypothesis 4: MSME operators are more willing to pay their taxes when other business owners will learn about their tax compliance. Hypothesis 5: MSME operators are more willing to pay their taxes when audits are more likely.

q17.value: To test Hypothesis 1, we will examine the difference in means across the list experiment treatment groups, by reliance on public services. We will follow Hainmueller et al. (2015) in conducting the conjoint experiment analysis to non-parametrically estimate the effects of each conjoint dimension, simultaneously testing hypotheses 2-5.

registration_responses.q1: Exploring Social and Group Dynamics of Tax Compliance: A Conjoint Experiment Among Zambian Taxpayers
registration_responses.q2: Brigitte Seim | Daniel Pemstein | Twivwe Siwale
registration_responses.q5: We acknowledge the support of the International Growth Centre in funding this project.

q2.value: John Gerring | Emanuel Coman | Brendan Apfeld | Stephen Jesse

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study seeks to test the accepted view that higher education leads to less traditional values. Causally assessing this relationship requires separating the effect of attending university from confounding factors that may be associated with both the decision to enroll into university and political views, such as personal characteristics, early childhood socialization, or peer groups. To circumvent these issues, the study proposes a regression discontinuity design in Romania.

q16.value: H1: University education leads to less traditional values. H2: The causal effect increases with additional years of tertiary education. H3: The causal effect is stronger for students who grow up in a rural area than for those who grow up in an urban area. H4: The causal effect is stronger for students in the humanities and social sciences than for students in other disciplines.

q17.value: The study attempts to test the hypotheses by taking advantage of a unique research design in Romania, where access to university is regulated by a high school exit exam, the baccalaureate (“Bac”) and the results of all exams are public. This allows for the implementation of a regression discontinuity design (RDD), whereby only high school graduates who fall just above and below the cutoff necessary to enroll into university will be sampled. The primary analysis will exploit a fuzzy regression discontinuity (RD) design based on scores to the Bac. The treatment is not assigned perfectly based on the Bac score as in a sharp RD, but it is much easier for students to attend university if they pass the Bac than if they do not; one can thus expect a large jump (discontinuity) in the probability of attending university when moving from a student who barely fails the Bac to one who barely passes. Once identified, the high school graduates in the target population will be contacted via Facebook and invited to take a survey that will assess, among other things, their traditional values. The questions in the questionnaire survey used to tap into a respondent’s traditional values are marked as TV (traditional values).

Once identified, the high school graduates in the target population will be contacted via Facebook and invited to take a survey that will assess, among other things, their traditional values. The questions in the questionnaire survey used to tap into a respondent’s traditional values are marked as TV (traditional values).

attributes.title: Candidate Entry & Vote Choice in the Wake of Incumbent Performance Transparency Initiatives

q1.value: Candidate Entry & Vote Choice in the Wake of Incumbent Performance Transparency Initiatives

q2.value: Guy Grossman | Kristin Michelitch | Carlo Prato

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The study explores the downstream effect of providing citizens with information on incumbent performance in Uganda. In the original study (Grossman and Michelitch, APSR, 2018), the PIs explored the effect of greater transparency on subsequent incumbent performance. In this study, the PIs explore the downstream effect of greater transparency on potential candidates entry and on voter choice.

q16.value: We formalize a theory of how incumbent performance, challenger entry in primaries and general elections, and citizen vote choice respond endogenously to civil society organization (CSO) led incumbent performance transparency initiatives occurring early in the electoral cycle. Our key argument is that these responses crucially depend on both the incumbent type and on her relative party advantage. Specifically, we hypothesis that (at the general election), higher transparency: (i) increases the incumbent I's winning probability and decreases the number of challengers when perceived performance is high (s = h) and the incumbent's party advantage is not too large; (ii) decreases the incumbent I’s winning probability and increases the number of challengers when perceived performance is low (s = l) and the incumbent's party advantage is not too large; (iii) otherwise, has no effect on I0s winning probability and number of challengers.

q17.value: We leverage two sources of identification in CSO-led incumbent performance transparency: (1) matching Ugandan districts where a CSO creates annual incumbent performance scorecards and disseminates to political elites to counterfactual (matched) districts; and (2) within the CSO-scorecard districts, a field experiment in which the CSO additionally disseminates the scorecard to citizens for randomly assigned incumbents for two years during the 2011-2016 electoral term. Specifically, we use four (hitherto) unmerged datasets: general election data from the electoral commission, incumbent survey data on councilor characteristics and primary elections, CSO performance (scorecard) data, and performance data culled from district plenary meeting minutes.

q19.value: Over 900 constituencies from 50 Ugandan subnational governments

attributes.title: Shared social identity and strategic uncertainty – Vol. 2

q1.value: Shared social identity and strategic uncertainty – Vol. 2

q2.value: Dominik Duell | Catherine Hafer | Dimitri Landa

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Frequently groups face collective action problems. We propose that strategic uncertainty may drive this phenomenon: Collective action often requires that individuals coordinate on taking an action that is costly with certainty, but that yields benefits only if enough others take similar actions. Individuals in more homogenous groups may face less uncertainty regarding how other groups members will behave, i.e. they may be more confident that enough of their fellow group members will also take the risky action, making them more willing to take the risky action themselves. We aim to distinguish this mechanism from the mechanism in which individuals’ preferences for benefiting those who share one’s social identity, or to hurt those who do not, drives the increased propensity to take the risky action in more homogeneous groups (as laid out in previous studies). We also investigate a mechanism where shared social identity implies shared beliefs about fellow in-group members’ types (i.e., risk preferences). We implement a laboratory experiment consisting of three stages. In stage 1, we elicit what subjects deem their two most important social group memberships and then, depending on a random draw, either assign subjects based on those stated social identities into two social identity groups of similar subjects or assign them randomly into two social identity groups (called “Klees” and “Kandinskys”). Subjects know that both assignment procedures are possible; they are not told that the probability assigned to the random procedure is .99. In stage 2, subjects retain the social identities from stage 1 but are assigned to decision groups of either size 2, 3, or 4. Decision groups may consist of individuals with different social identities. Each decision group then plays a stag hunt game: Each subject in each decision group chooses between two options “W” and “R”. Treatments vary how payoffs are determined: (Rule-1) If at least three subjects in the decision group play W, everyone receives a payoff w, while if at least three subjects play R, everyone receives a payoff r. If the coordination threshold is not met, those who play W receive a payoff x and those who play R receive a payoff y, where w>r>y>x. (Rule-2) If at least three subjects in the decision group play W, everyone who played W receives a payoff w while those who played R receive a payoff x, while if at least three subjects play R, everyone who played R receives a payoff r while those who played W receive a payoff y. If two subjects play W and two play R, everyone who plays W receives y, while everyone who plays R receives x. Subjects choose between option W and R for each of 20 rounds, and they are randomly re-matched into decision groups in each round. In some sessions, they are assigned to groups of size 2 or 3, and in some other sessions they are assigned to groups of 4, where the ratio of group members of one social identity to those of another is either 2:2 or 3:1. In stage 3, we elicit subjects’ risk preferences using the Bomb Game and elicit their beliefs about the average risk preference in either their social identity in-group or social identity out-group (between subject design).

q16.value: We test whether subjects are more likely to choose the welfare optimizing but more risky action W across different group sizes (2, 3, or 4), social identity group composition (more homogeneous, more diverse), and coordination thresholds (unanimous vs at least group size - 1). In particular, we test the claims that H1a: Individuals are more likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when the group is more homogeneous in social identity (Less strategic uncertainty mechanism 1). H1b: Individuals are more likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when the threshold for achieving coordination is lower (Less strategic uncertainty mechanism 2). H2: Individuals are less likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when the group contains fewer members of the individual’s social identity group (Preference mechanism). H3: Individuals are more likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when they belief those who share their social identity hold more similar risk preferences like themselves (Same type mechanism).

q17.value: We test our hypotheses by looking at individuals’ rate of taking the risky action W. In particular, we look at decision groups of 3 that either feature, from the perspective of a given subject, two subjects with shared social identity (3-2in), one other subject with shared social identity (3-1in), or two other subjects with a different social identity (3-2out). And, we look at decision groups of 4 that either feature, from the perspective of a given subject, two subjects with a shared social identity (4-2in), one other subject with a shared social identity (4-1in), or three other subjects with a different social identity (4-3out). Evidence for H1a is provided by observing no difference in E, averaging across all subjects, in 3-2in vs 3-1in and in 4-2in vs 4-3out but higher E in 4-2in or 4-3out vs 4-1in. Such pattern would indicate that more homogeneous groups, in terms of social identity, feature less strategic uncertainty but when the level of homogeneity is constant, behavior does not change. Evidence for H1b is provided when E is lower in the Rule-1 vs the Rule-2 treatment. Evidence for H2 is provided when we find E decreasing in the number of group members who do not share the individual’s identity, indicating a willingness to hurt the social out-group. Note, our design precludes any strategies that are driven by in-group favoritism is possible. Evidence for H3 is assessed by correlating E, between subject, and the difference between subjects’ risk preferences and their beliefs about others’ risk preferences. We implement proper independent or pair difference-in-means or difference-in-distribution tests as well as a regression including E, group composition, subjects’ risk preferences, and beliefs about risk preferences of others. In a pilot study conducted in 2018 (par group sizes of 4), we learned that in groups of 2, E is higher when subjects interact with someone who shares their identity, that E is higher in groups of 2 than groups of 3, and that switching Stage 2 and 3 does not affect results in Stage 2. Treatments Rule-1 and Rule-2 and H1b are extensions to a previously registered design: “Shared social identity and strategic uncertainty.”

In particular, we look at decision groups of 3 that either feature, from the perspective of a given subject, two subjects with shared social identity (3-2in), one other subject with shared social identity (3-1in), or two other subjects with a different social identity (3-2out). Evidence for H1a is provided by observing no difference in E, averaging across all subjects, in 3-2in vs 3-1in and in 4-2in vs 4-3out but higher E in 4-2in or 4-3out vs 4-1in. q2.value: John Gerring | Emanuel Coman | Brendan Apfeld | Stephen Jesse

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study seeks to test the hypothesis that higher education leads to more a more “liberal” or “left-wing” ideology. This is measured by questions gauging the individual’s position on the left-right spectrum and party affiliation. Causally assessing this relationship requires separating the effect of attending university from confounding factors that may be associated with both the decision to enroll into university and political views, such as personal characteristics, early childhood socialization, or peer groups. To circumvent these issues, the study proposes a regression discontinuity design in Romania.

q16.value: H1: University education fosters political liberalism. H2: University education fosters economic liberalism. H3: University education fosters overall liberalism, as judged on a left-right scale. H4: University education encourages deviation from parental party identification. H5: The main causal effect (H1) increases with additional years of tertiary education. H6: The main causal effect (H1) is greater for students from a rural background. H7: The main causal effect (H1) is stronger for students in the humanities and social sciences than for students in the natural sciences.

q17.value: The study attempts to test the hypotheses by taking advantage of a unique research design in Romania, where access to university is regulated by a high school exit exam, the baccalaureate (“Bac”) and the results of all exams are public. This allows for the implementation of a regression discontinuity design (RDD), whereby only high school graduates who fall just above and below the cutoff necessary to enroll into university will be sampled. The primary analysis will exploit a fuzzy regression discontinuity (RD) design based on scores to the Bac. The treatment is not assigned perfectly based on the Bac score as in a sharp RD, but it is much easier for students to attend university if they pass the Bac than if they do not; one can thus expect a large jump (discontinuity) in the probability of attending university when moving from a student who barely fails the Bac to one who barely passes. Once identified, the high school graduates in the target population will be contacted via Facebook and invited to take a survey that will assess, among other things, their ideology.

To circumvent these issues, the study proposes a regression discontinuity design in Romania.

H5: The main causal effect (H1) increases with additional years of tertiary education. H6: The main causal effect (H1) is greater for students from a rural background. attributes.title: Violent Displacement and Empathy: The Determinants of Hosting in Eastern Congo

q1.value: Violent Displacement and Empathy: The Determinants of Hosting in Eastern Congo

q2.value: Nik Stoop | Peter Van der Windt

q5.value: We thank RISD in Congo, Han Il Chang and Leonid Peisakhin for their comments on this design.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: The global population of forcibly displaced people has reached an all-time high. Over the past decade, their number strongly increased from 43.3 million in 2009, to 70.8 million by the end of 2018. The majority – an estimated 41.3 million – are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs). To address the needs of the displaced, humanitarian agencies such as the UNHCR – the United Nation’s Refugee Agency – have increasingly focused on local integration, calling on citizens to welcome refugees into their communities and homes. It is estimated that the majority of the world’s displaced (60%) are not hosted in camps, but find shelter in host communities, often sharing a house with host families. Despite the importance of hosting IDPs, we know surprisingly little about its dynamics. What motivates people to welcome the displaced? This study aims to answer this question in Congo.

q16.value: H1: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are more likely to host internally displaced people. H2: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to host internally displaced people. H3: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are less likely to hold negative attitudes towards internally displaced people. H4: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are less likely to hold negative attitudes towards internally displaced people. H5: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are more likely to share their endowment with internally displaced people in a dictatorship game. H6: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to share their endowment with internally displaced people in a dictatorship game. H7: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are both more likely to express a willingness to provide labor and to actually provide the labor. H8: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to express a willingness to provide labor and to actually provide the labor.

q17.value: Survey data and behavioral measures collection in the Congo.

registration_responses.q1: Violent Displacement and Empathy: The Determinants of Hosting in Eastern Congo
registration_responses.q2: Nik Stoop | Peter Van der Windt
registration_responses.q5: We thank RISD in Congo, Han Il Chang and Leonid Peisakhin for their comments on this design.

registration_responses.q16: H1: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are more likely to host internally displaced people. H2: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to host internally displaced people. H3: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are less likely to hold negative attitudes towards internally displaced people. H4: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are less likely to hold negative attitudes towards internally displaced people. H5: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are more likely to share their endowment with internally displaced people in a dictatorship game. H6: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to share their endowment with internally displaced people in a dictatorship game. H7: Individuals with a history of violent displacement are both more likely to express a willingness to provide labor and to actually provide the labor. H8: Individuals with a higher capacity to empathize with others are more likely to express a willingness to provide labor and to actually provide the labor.
registration_responses.q17: Survey data and behavioral measures collection in the Congo.

attributes.title: Structural and Interpersonal Factors Facilitating the Satisfaction of Group Members' Needs within Intergroup Contact Interactions

q1.value: Structural and Interpersonal Factors Facilitating the Satisfaction of Group Members' Needs within Intergroup Contact Interactions

q2.value: Ruth Ditlmann | Nurit Shnabel | Gali Pesin Michael | Julia Roseman | Ruben Below

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: The proposed research will examine whether and how the communication strategies used by members of historical perpetrator groups are shaped by their implicit motives. In particular, we will examine whether members of historical perpetrator groups who are dispositionally high in implicit power motive (IPM), that is, who are motivated to influence others and skillful at doing so, convey messages to members of historical victim groups that are more effective in promoting victims’ conciliatory tendencies as compared to the messages conveyed by low-IPM perpetrator group members. Our study centers on contemporary German-Israeli relations in which the perpetrator- victim dyad is chronically salient due to the Holocaust. First, participants' implicit power motive will be assessed using the PSE in a digital format. Participants’ responses will be coded for implicit power following Winter’s (1994) Manual for Scoring Motive Imagery in Running Text, by a trained coder, who will be blind to the hypothesis and experimental condition. After taking a break, participants will be told that we exchange letters between Israeli Jewish and German students, and it is their task to write a letter either to an Israeli Jewish or to a German participant (depending on random assignment to the two experimental conditions) about the importance of the Holocaust in contemporary German education. Participants' letters will be coded by a trained coder for empowering and non-empowering messages following our coding manual.

q16.value: Our main hypothesis examines whether perpetrator group members (i.e., Germans) who are high on IPM, who are naturally skillful communicators, convey more empowering and fewer non-empowering messages to members of the victim group (i.e., Jews) in discussions about historical injustices and their present implications. More specifically, we will test the prediction that the messages that high-IPM perpetrator group members convey to members of their victim group have different composition than the messages conveyed by low-IPM perpetrator group members, such that the percentage of empowering components to total components (i.e., empowering and non-empowering) would be higher in the messages conveyed by high-IPM perpetrator group members (as compared to low-IPM members).

q17.value: We will submit the percentage of empowering to total messages to an generalized linear model (GLM) with a logit link function and binomial distribution (see Baum 2008) where we enter condition dummy coded 0 and 1, the implicit power motive scores residualized, and their two-way interaction.

registration_responses.q1: Analogic Perspective-Taking and Attitudes Toward Teachers’ Unions
registration_responses.q5: We thank the Iowa State Educational Association and Mike Wiser for their support.
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q19: 4000 (3300 in nationally-representative sample, 700 from the Midwest)

q2.value: John Gerring | Emanuel Coman | Brendan Apfeld | Stephen Jesse

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study seeks to test whether university education diminishes tolerance for corruption and corrupt behavior. Causally assessing this relationship requires separating the effect of attending university from confounding factors that may be associated with both the decision to enroll into university and political views, such as personal characteristics, early childhood socialization, or peer groups. To circumvent these issues, the study employs a regression discontinuity design in Romania.

q16.value: H1: University education leads to less tolerance for corruption. H2: The causal effect increases with additional years of tertiary education. H3: The causal effect is greater for students growing up in a rural community than for students growing up in the suburbs and cities.

q17.value: The study attempts to test the hypotheses by taking advantage of a unique research design in Romania, where access to university is regulated by a high school exit exam, the baccalaureate (“Bac”) and the results of all exams are public. This allows for the implementation of a regression discontinuity design (RDD), whereby only high school graduates who fall just above and below the cutoff necessary to enroll into university will be sampled. The primary analysis will exploit a fuzzy regression discontinuity (RD) design based on scores to the Bac. The treatment is not assigned perfectly based on the Bac score as in a sharp RD, but it is much easier for students to attend university if they pass the Bac than if they do not; one can thus expect a large jump (discontinuity) in the probability of attending university when moving from a student who barely fails the Bac to one who barely passes. Once identified, the high school graduates in the target population will be contacted via Facebook and invited to take a survey that will assess, among other things, their views on corruption. The questions in the questionnaire survey used to tap into corruption are marked as C (corruption).
